Publication title: SDP develops guidelines to continue implementing DMCA
Comment on data source:
Sime Darby Plantation Bhd's (SDP) Indonesian subsidiary, Minamas Plantation (Minamas) has developed a guideline to continue implementing the Sustainable Community-based Fire Prevention or Desa Mandiri Cegah Api (DMCA) programme.

The oil palm plantation company said the DMCA, which was scheduled to be rolled out in March earlier, had proved to be challenging due to the movement restriction and social distancing protocols, resulted from the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

SDP said the setback has triggered the urgency for Minamas and its university partner, Universitas Tanjungpura to work together in developing the guideline.
Accessed by August 2021: Data source is unavailable. Page not found prompt is seen when accessing the website.
Accessed by August 2021: Data source is unavailable. Page not found prompt is seen when accessing the website.

Sime Darby Plantation’s operations in Indonesia is represented by our subsidiary Minamas Plantation, headquartered in Jakarta. Minamas has a presence in eight provinces with a total landbank of 256,247 ha, with oil palm planted area of 193,331 ha, of which about 82% is mature.

In Indonesia we own and operate 65 oil palm estates and 22 mills located in Sumatera, Kalimantan and Sulawesi.

Publication title: Palm Oil Still the Gold Standard: Minamas
Comment on data source:
Palm oil company Minamas Plantation, a local arm of Malaysia's conglomerate Sime Darby, said it is confident demand for palm oil will remain robust in the coming years, as populous countries like India and Pakistan as well as developed countries in Europe still have not found a cheaper alternative for cooking oil.

“Compared to other cooking oils like soybean, vegetable or sunflower, palm oil is still more efficient,” said Roslin Azmy Hassan, Minamas' head of plantation operations, in a recent statement.

Minamas produced over 3 million metric tons of fresh fruit bunches (FFB) and 845,957 metric tons of crude palm oil (CPO) in the 2014/2015 financial year, down from 4.1 million metric tons of FFB and 927,803 metric tons of COP in 2013/2014, in line with declining prices for the products in the global market.

Publication title: Serving Kalimantan Market,  Minamas Plantation Launches Alif Cooking Oil
Minamas Plantation is boosting palm oil replanting to work on the cooking oil market
Comment on data source:
PT Minamas Plantation continues to boost its oil palm replanting program . As of June 2019, Minamas has succeeded in rejuvenating an area of ​​55,000 hectares (ha) of its oil palm plantations. The replanting realization is equivalent to 43.5% of the total land area that urgently needs to be rejuvenated, covering an area of ​​97,440 ha.

Head of Plantation Upstream Indonesia Minamas Plantation Shamsuddin Muhammad said, the rejuvenation of the company's palm oil has been started since 2010 and then boosted since 2012 and continues to be improved to accelerate the company's rejuvenation program.

File: uploads/Philippines_ Dole to expand plantation area to meet new markets.pdf
Publication title: Philippines: Dole to expand plantation area to meet new markets
Comment on data source:
Pineapple grower Dole Philippines Inc. is currently on an expansion mode by as much as three quarters more of its current land area in south-central Mindanao to meet the requirement of the fruit-consuming Asian market, a company executive said.

Expanding by another 12,000 hectares would be equivalent to three-fourths of its current plantation size of 16,571 hectares scattered in the provinces of South Cotabato and Sarangani.

Melquiades L. Hernandez III, director of Dole Philippines corporate affairs division in its Polomolok office, said the search for lands has taken them as far as the central Mindanao province of North Cotabato and Bukidnon in central Mindanao. He said land acquisition may take the form of direct purchase, lease or growership. He said some landowners have offered their lands in exchange for buying out their indebtedness from banks and loan sharks.

File: uploads/farmlandgrab.org _ Itochu to invest US$57.7m in bananas.pdf
Publication title: Itochu to invest US$57.7m in bananas
Name: Gabrielle Easter
Comment on data source:
Leading Japanese trader Itochu will invest ¥6bn (US$57.7m) in banana production through its Dole business, reports Nikkei.
 
Itochu has set a goal of improving Asian banana production capacity 60 per cent by 2020 in a bid to secure supply for Japan, which will include upgrading farming methods, investing in irrigation and potentially moving farms to sites with better soil.       
 
Itochu’s wholly owned subsidiary Dole International Holdings reported a 30 per cent drop in banana production levels from 2012 to 2015, when it fell to 540,00 tonnes.

File: uploads/Expansion of agricultural plantations threatens Mindanao people’s survival.pdf
Publication title: Expansion of agricultural plantations threatens Mindanao people’s survival
Name: Ronalyn V. Olea
Comment on data source:
MANILA – – Some 300 indigenous peoples, farmers, workers, members of religious groups and the academe formed a network opposing the expansion of agricultural plantations in Mindanao.

At least 500,000 hectares of land in Mindanao are covered with agricultural plantations primarily for export. In the last ten years, big agricultural corporations aggressively expanded their operations. From 2005 to 2014, the land areas covered by the plantations increased by 79 percent, according to the research by the newly formed Network Resisting Expansion of Agricultural Plantations in Mindanao (REAP Mindanao Network).

File: uploads/Group nixes banana, pineapple farm expansion in SouthCot.pdf
Publication title: Group nixes banana, pineapple farm expansion in SouthCot
Name: Bong S. Sarmiento
Comment on data source:
KORONADAL CITY (MindaNews/13 February) – An alliance of local government units has strongly opposed the further expansion of banana and pineapple plantations in the town of T’boli in South Cotabato.

The Allah Valley Landscape Development Alliance (AVLDA) recently passed a resolution asking the Protected Area Management Board (PAMB) to deny requests for more banana and pineapple plantations due to environmental concerns, said South Cotabato Gov. Arthur Pingoy Jr., the body’s chairperson.

This came after members of the alliance conducted an ocular inspection in Barangay Salacafe in T’boli, a highland municipality.

The town hosts thousands of hectares of banana and pineapple plantations of Sumifru Philippines Corp. and Dole Philippines, Inc., respectively. They cannot be immediately reached for comments.

Sumifru is a subsidiary of Japan’s Sumitomo Corp. Dolefil, on the other hand, flexed its muscles in T’boli town after buying the bankrupt T’boli Agro-Industrial Development, Inc. years ago.

File: uploads/PSA REPORT ON PINEAPPLE MOST PROFITABLE CROP AN ILLUSION FOR FARMERS WITH GROWERSHIP AGREEMENTS WITH DOLE PHILIPPINES _ UMA Pilipinas.pdf
Publication title: PSA REPORT ON PINEAPPLE MOST PROFITABLE CROP AN ILLUSION FOR FARMERS WITH GROWERSHIP AGREEMENTS WITH DOLE PHILIPPINES
Comment on data source:
The Unyon ng mga Manggagawa sa Agrikultura (UMA) today called the attention of the Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) for misleading the public when it reported that pineapple is the most profitable crop for Filipino farmers.


This is an illusion for thousands of Filipino farmers and even agricultural workers, a number of which have become agrarian reform beneficiaries, and were forced to enter into growership and lease agreements with multinational companies such as Dole Philippines (Dolefil) in Polomolok and Tupi in South Cotabato.
In a new agreement with Dolefil, growers in the above places sell their pineapple to the now Japanese owned company at only P5 per kilo which is way below the PSA’s boast that farm gate prices are at P19.37 per kilo.


This means that said growers only have a gross income of P202,110 per hectare if 40,422 kg.are produced in one hectare. But their actual gross income is only P404,220 for a 3 year crop cycle as pineapples bear fruit after 18 months from planting.

File: uploads/Landbank releases P213 million loan for pineapple production _ Philstar.com.pdf
Publication title: Landbank releases P213 million loan for pineapple production
Name: Danessa Rivera
Comment on data source:
MANILA, Philippines — The Land Bank of the Philippines is supporting pineapple production in South Cotabato with a P212.8-million loan.

Landbank signed a loan with the Laconon 100 Multi-Purpose Cooperative (LMPC) to finance the co-op’s pineapple production and agricultural modernization efforts, to help sustain the growth of the local pineapple industry in the province.

The financial support is expected to boost the production of pineapple farms managed by LMPC, with a combined area of over 1,400 hectares in the municipalities of T’boli, Surallah, Lake Sebu and Banga.

Publication title: The Sour Taste of Pineapple:  How an Expanding Export Industry Undermines  Workers and Their Communities
Comment on data source:
Women in the Workplace
Filipino working women have been most affected by the growth of the pineapple industry. Most of the workers who where fired or offered voluntary resignation since Dolefil began to use labor fl exibilization in the 1980’s were regular women workers. The majority of the women working today are contract laborers from labor cooperatives. In the agriculture division, their job includes harvesting, planting, and field maintenance. In the manufacturing division, they
are in charge of the preparation, processing, warehouse packaging, and other tasks in the cannery.

File: uploads/PHILIPPINES_ Dole Philippines to double plantations – TFNet – International Tropical Fruits Network.pdf
Publication title: PHILIPPINES: Dole Philippines to double plantations
Comment on data source:
Dole Philippines (Dolefil) has embarked on an ambitious expansion scheme since it came under control of Japan’s Itochu Corporation, with plans to double its plantations in the next five years, website Sunstar.com.ph reported.

 

Dolefil corporate affairs division director Melquiades L. Hernandez III told the Davao Business Forum the company had the opportunity to expand its presence on the continent, and that from a production perspective the company was already looking at prospects in the areas of Sultan Kudarat, Davao del Sur, South Cotabato, and North Cotabato.

Publication title: Dole plans Philippine expansion
Comment on data source:
“We are working together with our local teams, local municipalities, and local partners to increase our hectares for pineapples. The same goes for other selected produce. We definitely plan to continue investing and growing our business here in the Philippines across the whole brand portfolio,” Mr. Wiegele said.
 
Mr. Wiegele said the firm had been growing its produce across more than 30,000 hectares of farmland that cover areas in Davao, General Santos City, Bukidnon, and Cagayan de Oro in Mindanao, and a small farm operation in Luzon.

File: uploads/To what extent has Philippine agriculture Undergone integration and consolidation_ State of agri-enterprise development in the Philippines.pdf
Publication title: To what extent has Philippine agriculture Undergone integration and consolidation? State of agri-enterprise development in the Philippines
Name: Arlene Inocencio, Alexis Baulita, and Albert Dale Inocencio
Comment on data source:
This study is part of an overall assessment of the Agriculture and Fisheries Modernization Act
(AFMA or R.A. 8435) which aims to evaluate the accomplishments of AFMA, assess the
prospects towards completing its objectives, and frame policy recommendations accordingly.
Specifically, this component is tasked with assessing AFMA Objective 4: “To encourage
horizontal and vertical integration, consolidation, and expansion of agriculture and fisheries
activities, group functions and other services through the organization of cooperatives, farmers
and fisherfolk’s associations, corporations, nucleus estates, and consolidated farms and to
enable these entities to benefit from economies of scale, afford them a stronger negotiating
position, pursue more focused, efficient and appropriate research and development efforts, and
enable them to hire professional managers” (Section 3.d). The review uses key indicators for
horizontal and vertical integration in Philippine crops, livestock and poultry, and fisheries
markets. Cases from Philippine Rural Development Program (PRDP) and ARBO-AVAs were
analyzed in terms of the four outcomes specified in Objective #4. The results indicate high
concentrations for most agricultural crops, livestock and fishing markets. In terms of vertical
integration however, most agriculture markets appear to be mostly (weakly) partially
integrated. These observations affect the state of market competition and profitability in
agriculture markets. If the results can be validated, this study suggests that there are
opportunities to better achieve AFMA Objective 4 and improve the outcomes for the
agriculture, livestock and fishing markets through: (1) adjustments in the cluster development
programs and activities; (2) establishment of an effective M&E system; (3) better defined roles
for government and establishment of the appropriate institutional structures; and (4) a deeper
understanding of the implications of horizontal and vertical integrations.

File: uploads/Co-op’s pineapple venture gets Landbank loan _ Inquirer Business_7eoNUbt.pdf
Publication title: Co-op’s pineapple venture gets Landbank loan
Name: Jordeene B. Lagare
Comment on data source:
MANILA  -An agricultural cooperative in a South Cotabato town has secured funding from state-run Land Bank of the Philippines (Landbank) to scale up its production of pineapples and pineapple fibers.

In a statement, Landbank said it recently granted a P224-million loan to the T’Boli Farm Growers Multi-Purpose Cooperative which will be utilized to expand its operations and output.

Another P34 million will be set aside to procure farm machinery and post-harvest facilities for hauling and land preparation, including tractors, service vehicles, trucks and a backhoe loader.

The remaining P10 million will go to bolstering the volume of pineapple fibers that the co-op is exporting to the United Kingdom.

Publication title: Astarta Annual Report 2022
Comment on data source: 4000 ha of land under Astarta’s management in the Chernihiv region that were under temporary occupation until the beginning of April 2022. The land was cleared of mines, unexploded shells, and sizeable metal fragments. In May 2022 one of Astarta’s employees — a civilian tractor driver working in the field — died from missile fired at the vehicle from a russian military aircraft. As a result of the mentioned russian military aircraft attack the tractor was destroyed. The estimated value of the machinery was EUR0 1m. The Company was also forced to reconsider its logistics modality.

Publication title: Case Study: Durable and Efficient Water Wells Will Complement an Innovative Agricultural Plantation in Ethiopia
Name: Roscoe Moss Company
Comment on data source: Agropeace Bio Ethiopia is developing an innovative agricultural plantation in Ethiopia, but faces challenges in drilling water wells due to difficult geological conditions. To ensure a reliable and efficient water supply, the company has selected louvered well screens from Roscoe Moss Company that are tailored to the terrain characteristics and can withstand corrosion. This choice will enable Agropeace Bio to maintain the efficiency and durability of its water system over time.

Publication title: Sustainable high yield castor oil production in a desert area in Ethiopia
Comment on data source: This article discusses sustainable castor oil production in a desert area of Ethiopia. through its subsidiary Agropeace Bio Ethiopia Plc. The project aims to create a commercial-scale castor farm, using advanced Israeli agricultural technology to achieve high yields while providing employment opportunities and improving local water access. Additionally, the project emphasizes corporate social responsibility, focusing on good working conditions, environmental impact mitigation, and gender equality by employing female workers at all levels.

Publication title: Biofuels, land grabbing and food security in Africa
Comment on data source: Biofuels, land grabbing and food security in Africa is a book that examines the impact of biofuel production and land acquisitions on food security in Africa, using Tanzania as a case study. The book explores the complex relationships between biofuel policies, land use changes, investment patterns, and food security outcomes. It highlights the challenges and opportunities associated with large-scale land acquisitions for biofuel production, including issues related to land tenure, community participation, and environmental sustainability. The book also provides recommendations for improving biofuel policies and investment practices in order to promote food security and rural development in Africa.

Publication title: Indian owned farm attacked in Gambella
The Duty to Cooperate as an Instrument of Operationalizing the Right to Development: The case of Foreign Agricultural Investment in the Lowlands of Ethiopia
Name: Tefera Addis
Comment on data source: Verdanta Harvests Plc, a subsidiary of the Indian-based Lucky Group Company, signed a land lease agreement with the Ethiopian Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development in 2010 to establish tea gardens, including eucalyptus, coffee, medicinal plants, and other crops. However, strong resistance emerged from community elders and local residents, arguing that the land was part of protected forest reserves in Ethiopia and should not be cleared for tea production. Despite the complaints and opposition, Verdanta Harvests began clearing the land and installing machinery. In October 2013, local communities, dissatisfied with the project, destroyed the company's buildings, machinery, and part of the tea plantation, valued at $140,000. Despite the violent attack, the company resumed its operations. A recent report from the Federal Ministry of Agriculture reveals that the company is not developing the land as stipulated in the investment contract and received only a "C" grade in its internal evaluation system. During the process, the Ethiopian Human Rights Commission (EHRC) received a complaint about the case but decided not to investigate further, referring the matter to the Ethiopian Institute of the Ombudsman, which also returned the case to the EHRC. In the background of this situation, there appears to be a possible political motivation behind the decision not to pursue the investigation. Additionally, the local non-governmental organizations Pact Ethiopia and Forum for Environment provided their input on the case to the EHRC, although they were not formally solicited.

Name: Richard Bennett
Comment on data source:
"Legally today the name is Addax Bioenergy Sierra Leone. However, we have recently filled to change the name to Sunbird Bioenergy Sierra Leone, and we expect this to take effect imminently. Sunbird Bioenergy Africa holds a 75.1% interest AOG holds a 24.9% interest (please note that AOG does not have any interest in Sunbird Bioenergy Africa - Mauritius).

AOG chose to downscale their investment in 2014/5 and consequently not all fields were replanted in 2015/6. THE PROJECT WAS NEVER ABANDONED. Sunbird became the majority shareholder and project manager on the 8th of September in 2016 and has a business plan to resume full operations by 2019. The project is currently producing power for the Government of Sierra Leone and producing ethanol which is being traded in Europe. please see our website for further details. www.sunbirdbioenergy.com The project is very operational and currently employees 2,400 seasonal agricultural workers.

The company is producing sugarcane, cassava and napier grass. We expect to add additional crops in 2018. We would classify the company as agriculture and renewable energy. "

Name: Richard Bennett
Comment on data source: "Sunbird Bioenergy Africa is majority owned by African individuals, and the remaining shares are owned by the management team. There has been no change to the share structure of the company in Sierra Leone since our last update. However, we have implemented the name change, and the official name of the company is now Sunbird Bioenergy (SL) Limited.  "

Publication title: Waves and legacies: the making of an investment frontier in Niassa, Mozambique
Name: Angela Kronenburg García, Patrick Meyfroidt, Dilini Abeygunawardane y Almeida A.
Comment on data source:
The study "Waves and legacies: the making of an investment frontier in Niassa, Mozambique" analyzes the evolution of land-use investment in Niassa, Mozambique, from the colonial period to the present. It focuses on how different waves of actors—including commercial agricultural investors, forestry companies, and Christian missionaries—have attempted to establish themselves in the region, often facing failures or significant challenges​. 
Matama Farm was established in 1979 near Lichinga, Mozambique. It was managed by Chinese workers, focused on rice production, and employed approximately 1,500 workers. During the Mozambican civil war, which began in 1977, the farm was abandoned and occupied by local farmers. Later, the land was transferred to the Mosagrius program, an agricultural colonization project that promoted the arrival of South African commercial farmers. However, when the state attempted to evict local farmers to make space for the South Africans, conflicts arose. Eventually, the South Africans abandoned the area​.
It was observed that the "Matama Farm" project is no longer listed among the company's projects.

Publication title: Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone The Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone (SSJFZ) is CapitaLand's only food project in China and it is managed by Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone Development and Management Co., Ltd, a joint venture between CapitaLand and the Jilin City Government. As a commercially-driven project with strong government support, the food zone is the first agricultural collaboration between Singapore and China.   SSJFZ spans 1,450 sq km with a core area of 57 sq km. It is strategically located in Jilin Province between Changchun and Jilin cities, two of Jilin Province's largest cities. Capitalising on the region's rich natural resources of black soil, clean waters and favourable natural climate, SSJFZ adopts modern agri-technologies to achieve its vision of becoming a world-class, integrated and sustainable model food zone to produce quality and safe food. SSJFZ is built on international standards of Disease Free Zone (DFZ) for Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) and an Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) which leverage the experience from the Singapore government.   Today, investors have settled in the start-up area of SSJFZ and the first of the goods produced under the "Brilliance 43N" brand, particularly the famed Jilin rice, has been launched for sale in both Singapore and China markets. For more information, please visit www.brilliancefoods.com KEY FACTS

Name: Nikki Barber
Comment on data source:
"Hi Angela, The 2,000 ha is correct. Aviv is a 2,000 ha plantation in the Songea Rural District of Southern Tanzania with 1,025 ha of planted Arabica coffee and a wet mill processing facility.  It is Rainforest Alliance and UTZ certified. Aviv volumes will be supplemented with a smallholder coffee programme which currently has 1,665 farmers, most of whom are already embraced by the Olam Livelihood Charter and who will be supported for future certification schemes. At peak season, the Aviv plantation employs up to 1,500 people. You might also find this press release on water of interest: http://olamgroup.com/news/coffee-plantation-tanzania-serves-water-stewardship-standard/#sthash.HJ79Gx2c.dpbs. I found the overall listings for Olam and I’ll see if any need updating.
Best regards
Nikki"

Publication title: 2020 Annual Impact and ESG Report The Silverlands Funds
China's Opium Substitution Programme in Northern Burma
Name: Tom Kramer & Kevin Woods
Comment on data source: Page 76

Publication title: Opium substitution, reciprocal control and the tensions of geoeconomic integration in the China–Myanmar Border
Comment on data source: Over the past decade, the Chinese state has launched a strategic opium substitution program to support agricultural firms in Yunnan province to invest in northern Myanmar, which is second only to Afghanistan in drug production. These Yunnanese firms are encouraged to collaborate with or hire ex-poppy farmers to plant rubber, sugarcane, tea, corn, and other crops so that these farmers can leave the drug economy successfully. This paper examines the context and challenges of this program through a framework that highlights the tensions between geopolitics and geoeconomics. At one level, the framework demonstrates how the geopolitics–geoeconomics relationship is reinforced by reciprocal control: the promise of monetary profits has become a strategic tool for the Chinese state to implement narcotics control in northern Myanmar. At another level, however, reciprocity is manifested unevenly as not all private producers respond to this strategy in a positive and engaged manner. This unevenness inevitably generates regulatory tensions at multiple scales and underscores, in turn, how border security remains intrinsically unstable vis-a-vis attempts at geoeconomic integration.

Publication title: The process of formation and development
Comment on data source:
Formation and development process

Dak Lak Rubber Company Limited (DAKLAORUCO) was established on December 6, 2004 in Tha Luong Village, Pakse City, Champasak Province, Lao PDR under Investment License No. 111-04/KH-DT dated December 6, 2004 of the Ministry of Planning and Investment of the Lao People's Democratic Republic and amended for the 4th time with Concession Registration Certificate No. 016-16/KD/DT4 dated March 30, 2016.

Publication title: 1- Dak Lak Rubber Company Limited in Laos (Daklaoruco) (with additional Laos company logo)
Comment on data source:
DRI invests in managing 2 subsidiaries:

1- Dak Lak Rubber Company Limited in Laos (Daklaoruco) (with additional Laos company logo)

– Charter capital: 25,000,000 USD

– Capital contribution ratio: 100%

– Address: Tha Luong Village, Pakse District, Champasak Province, Lao People's Democratic Republic

– Main business lines: Planting, caring for, exploiting, processing and consuming natural rubber

– Subsidiaries of Daklaoruco:

+ Farm 1: May Village, BaChieng District, Champasak Province, Laos

+ Farm 2: VangKhaNan Village, LaoNgam District, Salavan Province, Laos

+ Farm 3: NoongPaHet Village, PathumPhone District, Champasak Province, Laos

+ Farm 4: NoongKe Village, LaoNgam District, Salavan Province, Laos

+ Rubber processing factory: Noong Nam Khao Village, BaChieng District, Champasak Province, Laos

– Currently, Daklaoruco is managing 8,810.5 hectares of rubber, of which 7,779.28 hectares have been exploited; 498.64 hectares of cashew and 17.65 hectares of eucalyptus. 01 latex processing factory with a capacity of 18,000 tons/year. The garden grows well and produces high productivity, the average yield in 2017 was 2.37 tons/ha, of which the yield in the 6th year of business gardens reached over 3 tons/ha. The company's current processed products are mainly SVR 3L, SVR5, SVR10, SVR20, SVR CV50 and SVR CV60 with good product quality, all indicators meet the standards to meet customer requirements; The company has built a product quality inspection room that meets ISO/IEC 17025:2005 standards. Management system according to ISO 9001:2015 standard.

Publication title: Industry and business area
Comment on data source:
Business lines:

– Planting rubber trees; fruit trees.

– Care, exploitation, processing and consumption of natural rubber and fruit trees.

– Wholesale of rubber latex and agricultural products; Wholesale of rubber seedlings and other industrial plants.

– Wholesale of machinery and equipment for rubber production and processing, agricultural production.

Typical products : SVR 3L, SVR CV60, SVR CV50, SVR10, SVR 20, exported bananas

Business location:

Rubber plantations are grown in two provinces, Champasak and Salaval, in the Lao People's Democratic Republic.

Products are exported to the US, Germany, Spain, Belgium, India, Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, China, etc.

Fruit trees intercropped with rubber trees in Cu Kpo commune, Krong Buk, Dak Lak, Vietnam.

 

accessed 2021-04-28

Publication title: Dac Lac Rubber Company to open plantations in Lao
Comment on data source:
Vietnam's Dac Lac Rubber Company plans to reclaim 5,000ha of land in the southern Lao provinces of Champasac, Saravan and Atopu, half of which the company will use as a rubber plantation.

The plan is part of a US$30 million economic cooperation programme between Laos and Viet Nam to develop rubber plantations in Laos on 10,000ha of land.

In 2005, rubber trees were planted on 850ha of farm land in Champasac and Saravan provinces. The company expects to reach the overall programme target by 2008.

File: uploads/8044 PT BAP Ternyata Tak Kantongi Izin Usaha Kebun Sawit di Kalteng.pdf
Publication title: PT BAP Does Not Have a Palm Oil Plantation Business License in Central Kalimantan
Comment on data source:
PT Binasawit Abadi Pratama (BAP) does not have a palm oil plantation permit from the Central Kalimantan Provincial Government (Pemprov Kalteng). However, the company has been able to carry out its operations, allegedly polluting the environment.

This was revealed by the Head of the Central Kalimantan Provincial Investment and Integrated Services Agency (Kadis PMPTSP), Aster Bonawati. She has been in office since 2016 and was unaware of PT BAP's presence in her jurisdiction. Later, Aster admitted that she was aware of PT BAP's documents being returned because they did not meet the requirements for plantation permits after checking her official agenda book.

Publication title: BIG Assets (Benua Indah Group) Auctioned March
Comment on data source: According to this data source, the Office of State Assets and Jakarta Auction Services through the Pontianak KPKNL remained with its decision to auction off the assets of PT. Benua Indah Group (BIG) Plantation Division on March 20, 2009.  PT. Duta Sumber Nabati is said to be one of the debtors whose assets will be auctioned off.

Publication title: Overlapping Palm Oil License is loss for the People
Comment on data source: Based on BGA Group, based on the court treatise No. 134/2015 on May 26th 2015, the areas belonging to ex BIG, as the result of the auction in Court of Ketapang, reached 11.500 hectares. They consist of PT Subur Ladang Andalan, PT Duta Sumber Nabati, and PT Bangun Maya Indah. The auction was held on 8 May 2015 and PT Inti Sawit Lestari (Grup BGA) won it. As the winner in the auction, BGA Group changed the name of the company through National Land Agency, District of Ketapang. PT Duta Sumber Nabati (DSN) becomes PT Sentosa Prima Agro (SPA).

Publication title: Overlapping of Plantation Licensing is Detrimental to the Community
Comment on data source:
According to this source, the BGA group of corporations have conducted socialization throughout May to July 2015 to the community around the former Benua Indah Group land area. The socialization, which was attended by part of the community, village heads, management of cooperatives, task forces from 4 sub-districts and Members of the Regional Leadership Meeting (Muspida) of Ketapang District, also succeeded in arranging a schedule of visits to each village around the plantation which included 21 villages.

Based on the InfoSAWIT team's investigation, some of the areas of oil palm plantations that have been purchased from the auction results also overlap with the licensing of land areas with oil palm plantations owned by other companies.

File: uploads/8068 Masyarakat Adat di Sebuku Ditahan, Protes tidak Digubris.pdf
Publication title: Indigenous Peoples in Sebuku Detained, Protests Ignored
Comment on data source: According to Yohanes, this case occurred because the long-standing land conflict between the Sebuku community and PT KHL was never resolved. It started in 2004, when the company continued to operate on community land for which compensation had not been completed. Then, Yohanes continued, in 2009, the community demanded the settlement of their land case. "But KHL management still ignored them. The field person's answer to the community was, later when the oil palms have borne fruit, just harvest them sir. And the palms are taken care of by the community," Yohanes explained. He added that since the first harvest in 2016, the community has harvested the crops because they feel that their rights have not been settled.

Comment on data source:
Google translate: 
Sampit, Central Kalimantan, 13/12 (Antara) - The Regent of East Kotawaringin, Central Kalimantan, is being urged to address a number of large private companies that are considered to have broken their promises to repair the Sampit-Bagendang road section.
"The Regent must urge the plantation company to realize the agreement that was made in the previous MoU," said Deputy Chairman of the Kotim DPRD, Parimus in Sampit, Friday.
Parimus deeply regrets the attitude of the company in question, because previously there had been an agreement between the government and the company coordinated by PT Pelabuhan Indonesia (Pelindo) III Sampit to jointly repair the road.
Companies That Break Promises to Fix Roads Must Be Addressed
"The Regent must urge the plantation companies to realize the agreements that have been made in the previous MoU,"
It was recorded that there were nine companies that signed the consortium agreement, namely PT Pelindo III Sampit Branch, PT Sinar Mas Group, PT Agro Indomas Group, PT Wilmar Group, PT Sukajadi Sawit Mekar, PT Mulia Agro Permai, PT Uni Primacom, PT
Surya Into Sawit Kahuripan and PT Sapta Karya Damai.
However, until now, only four companies have realized their assistance, namely PT Mulia Agro Permai, PT Wilmar
Group, PT Sinar Mas Group, and PT Uni Primacom.

Publication title: KLK buying Indon planter
Ratusan Warga Tutup Akses PT MAP Desak Realisasikan Plasma
Comment on data source: Google Translate: SAMPIT – Plantation conflicts continue to emerge. Not even a week after hundreds of residents of Sebabi Village stormed the Kotim DPRD, now it is the turn of the people of three villages to block the land owned by PT Mulia Agro Permai (MAP) on Jalan Jenderal Sudirman Km 29. The people of the three villages forcibly closed the plantation road by installing a portal. The action to close the company's access was carried out by around 300 residents from three villages, including Tanah Putih Village, Soren Village, and Pasir Putih Sub-district. They carried out the action based on the Regulation of the Minister of Environment and Forestry Number 51 of 2001. Article 5 states the obligation to facilitate 20 percent of plasma for the community. In addition, referring to the Decree of the Minister of Environment and Forestry Number SK.268/MENLHK/SETJEN/PLA.2/6/2018 concerning the Task Force for the Acceleration of the Implementation of Land Objects of Agrarian Reform (TORA) from Forest Areas and Social Forestry. Based on the ministerial decree, PT MAP is required to provide 20 percent of plasma land from the land released from forest areas. "PT Mulia Agro Permai is required to implement the ministerial decree, because it is related to the permit to release the area they obtained," said M Auri, the action coordinator. The action, he said, will continue to be carried out until the government and the company are willing to sit together and carry out these obligations. This is because they have been waiting too long for a resolution of the conflict with the foreign-owned company. "This action is the result of the failure to accommodate the RDP application letter that has been submitted many times to the DPRD," he said.

Publication title: HSBC and the Palm Oil Sector in South East Asia: towards accountability
Derita Warga Dusun Muara Ubar Kotim, dari Jalan Rusak, Listrik dan Tenaga Medis Tidak Ada
Comment on data source:
Google Translate: The Suffering of Muara Ubar Hamlet Residents in Kotim, from Damaged Roads, Electricity and Medical Personnel
By Editorial Team - June 4, 2021
The road is badly damaged, there are no medical personnel and teachers and electricity in Muara Ubar Hamlet, Tanah Putih Village, Telawang District, Kotim Regency, that's what 95 families of Muara Ubar Hamlet residents feel.
Head of RT 07 Muara Ubar Hamlet, Samsudin, said that the road to Muara Ubar Hamlet, Tanah Putih Village, Telawang District, Kotim, is badly damaged.
"The road to Muara Ubar Hamlet has never been repaired by PT. Mulia Agro Permai (MAP), if they only help so much, the residents of Muara Ubar Hamlet still buy diesel fuel," he said, Friday, June 4, 2021.
Just look at it yourself, the road to Muara Ubar Hamlet is impassable, badly damaged, the company never helps. We do it ourselves by working together. Even if they are helped, the residents of Muara Ubar hamlet always work together to buy diesel for the equipment provided by PT. MAP.
"The company's equipment, but we buy the diesel together with the residents," he said.
Ahmadi, a resident of Muara Ubar Hamlet, Telawang District, Kotim Regency, agreed with the RT head that we have never been helped by the company.
"To repair the road, we do community service, if it's our company, the residents of Muara Ubar Hamlet also collect funds together, such as buying land for the road," he said.
Not only the road, according to this media's monitoring, residents did not receive plasma from PT. MAP even though the number of
families in Muara Ubar hamlet is around 95 families.
CSR has never been enjoyed by Muara Ubar hamlet, even though the company PT. MAP (Mulya Agro Permai) KLK Group is located around Muara Ubar hamlet.
In addition, Muara Ubar hamlet has not been lit by electricity until now, "it's as if we are being treated as stepchildren," said Ahmadi.

Ahmadi explained that in Muara Ubar Hamlet there is a school, namely SDN-3 Tanah Putih, but learning activities are only once a week.
"Learning is only once a week, because there are no teachers, and there are 3 teachers but they live in Sampit, they come to teach once a week," he said.
In addition, there is a Muara Ubar Hamlet Polindes building, which has been built for 1 year but has not been used because there are no medical personnel.
"We hope that the Regional Government can help us with our difficulties, from the access road to the hamlet to the health problems in Muara Ubar Hamlet," he asked.

Publication title: Penyitaan Lahan Perkebunan Terus Berlanjut, PT MAP Jadi Sasaran
Comment on data source:
Google Translate: SAMPIT, radarsampit.jawapos.com – The Task Force (Satgas) has carried out the regulation of areas that encroach on forest areas that have been affected by plasma that has been enjoyed by the community. This is because some of the areas that have been regulated are plasma and independent cooperatives.
"As we know, the Garuda Task Force has begun to enforce the law related to forest areas where Kotim is also a target. So it is possible that later there will be cooperatives or plasma that are constrained or hampered by the regulation process," said Kotim Regent Halikinnor,
Sunday (3/16).
Halikinnor said that in the near future he would attend a special meeting in Palangka Raya with the Head of the District Attorney's Office and the PKH Task Force Team.
palm oil plantation Thousands of Hectares of PT Agro Bukit Plantation Confiscated by the State, Apparently This is the Cause Halikinnor continued, the regulation would likely have an impact on the community receiving plasma. The areas that have been regulated include a number of plasma and independent cooperatives. On the other hand, with the regulation, it is expected that the company can carry out its obligations properly to obtain legal certainty. "There are still many company obligations, especially the obligation of 20 percent plasma and CSR programs that have not been implemented optimally. We hope that with this law enforcement, everything will become clear," said Halikinnor. Thus, he added, the rights of the community and the region that have not been received optimally can be improved and maximized. His party fully supports the law enforcement. The confiscated land is 1,276 hectares which is considered to be in the forest area. The Task Force also confiscated PT Mananjung Hayak's land on Jalan Jenderal Sudirman km 45 with an area of ​​1,728 hectares. Installation of confiscation signs carried out by the Task Force together with the Kajari After PT Agro Bukit, the Violating Palm Oil Cooperative is Also Targeted for Confiscation of Plantation Land Continues, PT MAP Becomes the Target - Radar Sampit Kotim Donna R Sitorus, Kotim Police Chief AKBP Rezky MZ, and Dandim 1015 Sampit Letkol Tandri Subrata. The confiscation is intended so that land in the forest area is not tampered with by anyone without permission from the Task Force formed by President Prabowo Subianto

File: uploads/Kasum TNI Tinjau Langsung Penertiban Kawasan Hutan di Kotim - Sawitku Id.pdf
Publication title: Kasum TNI Tinjau Langsung Penertiban Kawasan Hutan di Kotim
Comment on data source:
Google Translate: SAWITKU - Lieutenant General of the TNI Richard Tampubolon, as the Chief of General Staff (Kasum) of the TNI, descended directly to Kotawaringin Timur Regency (Kotim), Central Kalimantan, to oversee the operation of forest order carried out by the Garuda Task Force Order of Forest Areas (PKH).

"As stipulated in Article 7 Paragraph (2) of Law Number 34 of 2004 on the TNI, one of the duties in Military Operations Other than War (OMSP) is to assist the government in law enforcement and maintain public order," Richard said in Kotim, Tuesday, March 18, 2025.

On the agenda, Kasum TNI was accompanied by various high-ranking officials, including the Head of the Police Criminal Investigation Agency, the Young Prosecutor General for Special Criminal Acts, the Head of the Geospatial Information Agency, as well as a number of other officials from the Ministry of Finance, BPKP, and SOEs.

This group was welcomed by Commander Kodam XII / Tanjungpura, Maj. Gen. Jamallulael, as well as Commander of the Garuda PKH Task Force, General of TNI Yusman Madayun.

A number of regional officials, such as the Regent of Kotim, Dandim 1015 / Sampit, the Chief of the Kotim State Prosecutor, and the Chief of Police of Kotim, were also present at the event.

This order focuses on the land located on Jalan Jenderal Sudirman Km 26 Sampit, which is an area owned by PT Globalindo Alam Perkasa (GAP). The TNI cassum along with the present officials carried out the installation of the confiscation sign as a sign that the land area of 12,069.39 hectares was again the property of the state.

"This operation aims to restore the assets of the country in the forest area so that it can be utilized for the welfare of the community," explained Richard.

Previously, the Garuda PKH Task Force has also conducted orders in several oil palm plantation companies, including PT Agro Bukit covering an area of 3,798.9 hectares, PT Mulia Agro Permai (MAP) covering an area of 1,276 hectares, and PT Mananjung Hayak covering an area of 1,728 hectares.

This order not only takes place in Kotim, but also simultaneously in 19 provinces from North Sumatra to Papua. Until March 18, 2025, this operation has recorded success in ordering 317 thousand hectares of forest areas.

The Garuda PKH task force found about 312 thousand hectares of land in Central Kalimantan whose use is not in accordance with regulations, so there are still many areas that are the next target of order.

The lands that are successfully secured will be returned to the state to be utilized for the welfare of the community, in accordance with the vision of President Prabowo Subianto. This step shows the presence of the state in completing various land problems as a whole.

In addition to securing state assets, this operation is also aimed at accelerating environmental protection and ensuring the use of forest areas for public interest.
Annual Report Agromino 2019.

PT Gunung Mas Raya Rohil Belum Bayarkan Tunjangan Karyawan
Comment on data source: Translated through Google: RADARBISNIS.CO.ID - Members of the Rokan Hilir Regency DPRD, Riau Province, admitted to being annoyed by the news that residents of Pematang Sikek Village, Rimba Melintang District, were fired by PT Gunung Mas Raya without receiving employee benefits. "We ask that this not happen. All companies operating in Rohil, in addition to having to respect the needs of employees, must also respect the local Manpower and Transmigration Office, because every job seeker is required to bring a yellow letter from the agency," said Member of Commission C of the Rohil DPRD Ucok Muhktar to reporters in Bagansiapiapi, Thursday. According to him, if there is a termination of employment rights from the company to employees, there should be a severance payment of one month's salary with the calculation of the length of time the person concerned has worked. "If it is true that the employee was fired without being given severance pay, we should not accept it, take firm action against the company," he said. He also asked the relevant agencies to give a grace period for claimants to speak to the government or accompany the person concerned. In addition, he also asked employees who had been dismissed to meet him.

File: uploads/Puluhan Masyarakat Rohil Gelar Orasi Tuntut Hak Plasma dari PT Salim Ivomas Pratama Group_go65l0H.pdf
Name: Puluhan Masyarakat Rohil Gelar Orasi Tuntut Hak Plasma dari PT Salim Ivomas Pratama Group
Comment on data source:
Google translate: ROHIL (RA) – Dozens of people who are members of the Sinembah Jaya Abadi Rohil Cooperative held an oration action in the plantation area of ​​PT Gunung Mas Raya, part of PT Salim Ivomas Pratama Group, on Monday (9/12/2024).
This action was led by Suranto, the Cooperative Chairperson and field coordinator (korlap), as a form of protest against the failure to realize the community's rights regarding the distribution of plasma land amounting to 20 percent of the company's total land.
According to Suranto, the action was triggered by the company's indifference to the community's demands which had previously been emphasized in the Rokan Hilir Regent's decree dated April 7, 2021.

The letter stated that PT Gunung Mas Raya was required to hand over 20 percent of its 12,825 hectares of land to the community in the form of plasma plantations.
"We have been patient enough, but until now there has been no good faith from the company to fulfill their obligations. This is not only a disregard for the community's rights, but also a violation of the law," said Suranto.

Suranto also revealed that the previous mediation, facilitated by the Rokan Hilir Police on March 21, 2023, did not produce a satisfactory solution.
"The company seemed to be washing its hands of it and ignoring its responsibilities. We hope that the local and central governments will immediately intervene to resolve this problem," he added.
Bagan Sinembah Police Chief, Commissioner Imron Teheri, and his staff went to the location of the demonstration to peacefully stop the speeches. He also facilitated mediation between the community and representatives of PT Salim Ivomas Pratama Group to find a way out of the conflict. However, the mediation again failed to produce an agreement.
"We are trying so that both parties can reach a fair and peaceful agreement. However, until now, the discussion has reached a dead end," explained Commissioner Imron Teheri.
Suranto emphasized that the demonstration would continue if their demands were not met.
"We are ready to mobilize a larger mass to fight for the rights of the local community. This struggle will continue until our rights that have been taken away since 1983 are returned," he concluded.
The conflict between the community and the company has become a public spotlight, especially regarding the plantation company's commitment to fulfilling its legal obligations to the local community. All parties hope for an immediate resolution to avoid escalating the conflict in the future.

File: uploads/Masyarakat Tuntut Perkebunan PT Gunung Mas Raya_6pmvTIa.pdf
Publication title: Masyarakat Tuntut Perkebunan PT Gunung Mas Raya
Comment on data source:
Google translate: Riauaktual.com - The community that is part of the Sinembah Jaya Abadi Rohil Cooperative group is still fighting to claim its rights to the PT Gunung Mas Raya or PT Salim Ivomas Pratama Group plantation. The demand is that 20% of the 12,825 hectares of plantation area controlled is the community's right. According to the Head of the Sinembah Jaya Abadi Rohil Cooperative, Suranto, the 20% land rights are approximately 2,565 hectares of land controlled by PT. Gunung Mas Raya. This has been regulated in Law Number 39 of 2014 concerning Plantations. Since the establishment of PT Gunung Mas Raya in 1986 until now, the community's rights have not been realized or handed over. And the struggle of this community group began in 1998,'' said Suranto

He explained that on September 30, 1998, an agreement was made between the community and PT. Gunung Mas Raya which was stated in a letter of agreement and had been agreed upon and signed by the company and was acknowledged by the local government apparatus at that time. However, it has not yet been realized to the community.

Based on the alleged failure to comply with the agreement that had been agreed upon, and there was no good intention from PT. Gunung Mas Raya, the community submitted a notification letter to the police for the peaceful oration activity that would be held on Tuesday (21/3/2023) yesterday

In response to this, the Rokan Hilir Police provided facilities for mediation between the community and PT. Gunung Mas Raya, however, from the results of the mediation and deliberation that had been carried out, no bright spot or agreement was found. "We would like to thank the Rohil Police who have provided facilities for mediation with PT. Gunung Mas Raya, but we are disappointed with PT. Gunung Mas Raya who have not provided a definite response or answer to this problem," explained Suranto. "We, the community, will continue to be enthusiastic and fight to fight for our rights as small people, this plantation law was made by the government for the welfare of the community, not to make the community miserable, but there are still parties who try to fight against the law that has been ratified by the government, and try not to pay attention to the welfare of the community," said Suranto again. "According to the applicable regulations, PT. Gunung Mas Raya should have handed over the rights to the Plasma plantation land to the community since its establishment 3 years ago, but until now the community has not received these rights, therefore I and other members of the community will take the path to a higher level to resolve this problem, if necessary we will take criminal and civil legal channels to fight for the rights of the small people," he explained again. "We hope that the government will pay attention to the problems that society is experiencing, and take firm action against companies that do not implement or implement the applicable regulations," he hoped.

Comment on data source:
"As an oil palm company that prioritizes the principles of sustainable oil palm plantation management and is also in line with the mandate of the law and government policy which states that companies engaged in oil palm plantations are expected to be able to carry out partnership activities with the surrounding community.

    This principle is applied by PT Palma Plantasindo to 430 heads of families (KK) of oil palm farmers in a number of villages in the company area which are members of the Sungebatu Sejahtera Sawit Cooperative, Sunge Batu Village, Pasir Belengkong District. Marking this partnership, Monday (14/10) at the Sunge Batu Village meeting hall, a conversion of the plasma plantation system by PT Palma Plantasindo operator to the Sungebatu Sejahtera Sawit Cooperative was held."

Organisation: Instituto Nacional de Colonização e Reforma Agrária (INCRA)

The database is updated monthly (on the 1st of each month).
